entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French or Late Latin; Anglo-French, from Late Latin expensa, from Latin, feminine of expensus, past participle of expendere

def.dt: :the act or an instance of expending :expenditure
:something expended to secure a benefit or bring about a result
:financial burden or outlay :cost built the monument at their own expense
:an item of business outlay chargeable against revenue for a specific period
:a cause or occasion of expenditure an estate is a great expense

:a loss, detriment, or embarrassment that results from some action or gain :sacrifice everyone had a good laugh at my expense usually used in the phrase at the expense of develop a boy's physique at the expense of his intelligence Bertrand Russell
:an account of expenses reimbursable to an employee
:the right of charging expenses to such an account
